title: Determinants and Inverses: Invertibility Criterion
contentHtml:
The invertibility criterion is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that helps us determine whether a matrix has an inverse or not.

Given a square matrix A, its determinant det(A) can be used to check if it's invertible. If the determinant is non-zero (det(A) â‰  0), then A is invertible and we can find its inverse using various methods like adjugate matrices and Cramer's rule.

title: Determinant and Adjugate Matrix
contentHtml:
The determinant of a square matrix A is intimately connected to its invertibility.

A matrix A has an inverse if and only if its determinant is non-zero.
